title: CoSMoS - Coastal Storm Modeling System
summary: "The Coastal Storm Modeling System (CoSMoS) makes detailed predictions of storm-induced coastal flooding, erosion, and cliff failures over large geographic scales. CoSMoS was developed for hindcast studies, operational applications and future climate scenarios to provide emergency responders and coastal planners with critical storm-hazards information that can be used to increase public safety, mitigate physical damages, and more effectively manage and allocate resources within complex coastal settings." See 'Overview': https://www.usgs.gov/centers/pcmsc/science/coastal-storm-modeling-system-cosmos?qt-science_center_objects=0#qt-science_center_objects Model Name (Name of the model, including acronyms): CoSMoS - Coastal Storm Modeling [...]
body:
"The Coastal Storm Modeling System (CoSMoS) makes detailed predictions of storm-induced coastal flooding, erosion, and cliff failures over large geographic scales. CoSMoS was developed for hindcast studies, operational applications and future climate scenarios to provide emergency responders and coastal planners with critical storm-hazards information that can be used to increase public safety, mitigate physical damages, and more effectively manage and allocate resources within complex coastal settings."

See 'Overview': https://www.usgs.gov/centers/pcmsc/science/coastal-storm-modeling-system-cosmos?qt-science_center_objects=0#qt-science_center_objects

Model Name (Name of the model, including acronyms):

CoSMoS - Coastal Storm Modeling System

Model Version (Version of the model, (i.e., 2.0)):

Abstract (Description or summary of the model, including its purpose or goals and the type or formalism of the model (e.g., system dynamic, agent based model, machine learning), preferably accompanied by relevant keywords):

"The Coastal Storm Modeling System (CoSMoS) makes detailed predictions of storm-induced coastal flooding, erosion, and cliff failures over large geographic scales. CoSMoS was developed for hindcast studies, operational applications and future climate scenarios to provide emergency responders and coastal planners with critical storm-hazards information that can be used to increase public safety, mitigate physical damages, and more effectively manage and allocate resources within complex coastal settings."

See 'Overview': https://www.usgs.gov/centers/pcmsc/science/coastal-storm-modeling-system-cosmos?qt-science_center_objects=0#qt-science_center_objects

Contact Name(s) and Email Address(es) (Names of person(s) responsible for maintenance of the model along with their email):

Patrick Barnard (pbarnard@usgs.gov), Li Erikson (lerikson@usgs.gov), Alan Allwardt (aallwardt@usgs.gov), Cara A Nadler (cnadler@usgs.gov)

U.S. Geological Survey

Water Resources

License (OSI-approved (Open-Source Initiative) license (see https://opensource.org/licenses)):

Identifier (Location where the model is posted or published (e.g. PID or DOI)):

Language (Computer language or platform used for programming (e.g., Fortan, R, Python)):

References (References (where the model has been cited, outputs, data release):

Barnard, P.L., Erikson, L.H., Foxgrover, A.C., Limber, P.L., O'Neill, A.C., and Vitousek, S., 2018, Coastal Storm Modeling System (CoSMoS) for Central California, v3.1 (ver. 1f, May 2020): U.S. Geological Survey data release, https://doi.org/10.5066/P9NUO62B.

O'Neill, A.C., Erikson, L.H., Barnard, P.L., Limber, P.W., Vitousek, S., Warrick, J.A., Foxgrover, A.C., and Lovering, J., 2018, Projected 21st century coastal flooding in the Southern California Bight. Part 1: Development of the third generation CoSMoS model: Journal of Marine Science and Engineering, https://doi.org/10.3390/jmse6020059.

Resources (Resources (how to use the model, where to download it, related publications, other webpages about the model (in other catalogs), USGS webpage):

USGS Webpage: https://www.usgs.gov/centers/pcmsc/science/coastal-storm-modeling-system-cosmos?qt-science_center_objects=0#qt-science_center_objects

Image (URL for an image that best represents the model, title of image, alternate text, URL of source):

'CoSMoS model flood duration for San Diego'

'Example of CoSMoS model output for San Diego showing duration of flooding. Results displayed on Our Coast, Our Future flood mapper.'

https://www.usgs.gov/media/images/cosmos-model-flood-duration-san-diego
